author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL says oil min move on KG-D6 cost-recovery illegal
description: As the Oil Ministry readies to take action against Reliance Industries for the fall in output from the KG-D6 gas fields, the Mukesh Ambani-led firm has warned that any attempt to limit cost-recovery is illegal and will be challenged in court.
tags: Business, KG-D6 gas fields, Reliance Industries
articleBody: As the oil ministry readies to take action against Reliance Industries for the fall in output from the KG-D6 gas fields, the Mukesh Ambani-led firm has warned that any attempt to limit cost-recovery is illegal and will be challenged in court. The ministry and its technical arm, the DGH, are upset with RIL because production from the Dhirubhai-1 and 3 (D1 and D3) gas fields in the prolific KG-D6 block has fallen from 61 million cubic metres per day in March, 2010, to about 37 mmcmd, instead of rising to 61.88 mmcmd, as projected by the company when it got its USD 8.8 billion capital expenditure plan for development of the field approved in 2006. The ministry has attributed the fall in output to non-fulfillment of RIL's commitment to drill 22 wells in the field. RIL has so far spent USD 5.694 billion on the two fields and has recovered USD 5.258 billion from the sale of gas produced. However, the ministry wants to limit cost recovery in the block in proportion to the slippage in output vis-a-vis the stipulated timeline, reducing RIL's entitlement to USD 3.405 billion. The firm however feels such a move would be ultra vires, or beyond the ministry's powers, as the Production Sharing Contract (PSC) does not have any such provision and the USD 1.85 billion already recovered by RIL cannot be reversed. &quot;If the PSC were indeed to be re-written to link cost recovery to levels of production, it would also have to include provisions for allowing the contractor (RIL) to recover costs in excess of his investment in case he were to achieve a rate of production higher than that estimated at the time of capex approval,&quot; RIL senior vice-president (commercial) B Ganguly wrote to the ministry on September 16. RIL said production below the original estimates meant the company loses its right to recover its investment within the originally estimated timeframe, causing huge losses in terms of sunk capital. Besides, RIL has already suffered huge erosion of market cap due to news of the fall in production. RIL said as per the PSC, all costs and production numbers provided in the field development plan (like the one approved for KG-D6 in 2006) are only estimates based on the understanding of the reservoir and the market prices at any given point of time and &quot;such estimates cannot be construed as constituting a commitment under the PSC.&quot; KG-D6 wells did not perform as per the FDP, as a severe drop in reservoir pressure and acute water ingress has already forced closure of two out of the 18 well drilled so far. The Oil Ministry's views have been backed by Solicitor General of India that said RIL should not be allowed to recover the cost of facilities that remain underutilised due to lower than anticipated output at its KG-D6 gas field. SGI Rohinton F Nariman on August 17 opined that &quot;the cost/expenditure incurred in constructing production/processing facilities and pipelines that are currently underutilised/have excess capacity cannot be recovered&quot;. &quot;There is no provision under the production sharing contract (PSC) that can limit cost-recovery to either production levels achieved by a contractor or to the extent that facilities are utilised under a development plan at any given point of time,&quot; RIL wrote. &quot;To even suggest that the contractor should, over and above this loss, forego his basic investment by foregoing cost recovery would be contrary to the fundamental notion of the PSC,&quot; it said. &quot;Any such attempt being contrary to the letter as well as spirit of the PSC would only trigger unnecessary disputes between the contractor and the government leading to needless arbitration proceedings,&quot; it added. The initial field development plan (FDP) for the D1 and D3 gas fields in the KG-DWN-98/3 block (KG-D6) envisaged a capex of USD 2.47 billion at a peak production rate of 40 mmcmd from 14 wells. Subsequently, RIL submitted an addendum saying the size of the gas reserves was twice the estimate of 5.32 tcf in the initial plan, at 11.3 trillion cubic feet. It proposed a USD 8.835 billion capex over two phases and envisaged a peak output of 80 mmcmd from 31 producing wells by April, 2012. Commercial gas production from the D1 &amp;amp; D3 fields commenced from April 1, 2009. RIL in December, 2009, tested its field production facilities at their full rated capacity of 80 mmcmd, during which time an average gas rate of 77-80mmcmd was maintained for a brief period of three days. Subsequently, the gas production rate was maintained at 57-61 mmcmd for a four-month period (January, 2010, to April, 2010). Subsequently, the gas production rate has gradually declined and the current rate is about 37 mmcmd, as against the approved FDP rate of 61.88 mmcmd for the year 2011-12. RIL says the gas production rate will remain in the range of 40-38 mmcmd, as against the projected peak of 80 mmcmd, till mid-2013 and also that no new well will hooked up to production facilities till mid-2013-14. The ministry claims that the DGH has repeatedly asked RIL to comply with the approved FDP work programme by drilling two more wells and connecting two other wells to its production system by the first quarter of 2011-12 fiscal. It asked RIL to drill another nine wells by March 31, 2012. However, RIL has failed to comply with the directive and to penalise the firm, the Oil Ministry has now threatened to restrict cost-recovery on a pro rata basis at the current production rate of 37 mmcmd, reducing RIL's entitlement to USD3.405 billion.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance' KG-D6 gas output dips below 45 mmscmd
description: Reliance Industries' eastern offshore KG-D6 oil and gas fields have seen output further dipping to 44.5 million standard cubic metres per day this month.
tags: Business, KG-D6, oil and gas fields, R P N Singh, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Reliance Industries' eastern offshore KG-D6 oil and gas fields have seen output further dipping to 44.5 million standard cubic metres per day this month. Reliance produced 44.5 mmscmd of natural gas during the week ended September 5 as against 44.8 mmscmd production last month, according to the status report filed by the company with the oil ministry here. The output comprised 37.1 mmscmd from Dhirubhai-1 and 3 (D1 and D3) gas fields and 7.4 mmscmd from MA oil field in the KG-DWN-98/3 or KG-D6 block. D1 and D3 gas fields produced 37.7 mmscmd of gas in August, while output from MA field was 7.1 mmscmd. As per the status report, out of the 22 wells to be drilled in the Phase-I of Dhirubhai-1 and 3 field development plan, 18 wells have been drilled and completed so far. Of these, 16 wells were put on production as two wells (B2 and B13) were kept closed due to high water cut. MA oilfield produced an average of 14,080 barrels of crude oil per day besides the 7.4 mmscmd of associated gas. Of the total 44.5 mmscmd, about 13.8 mmscmd of gas was sold to fertiliser plants and another 24.1 mmscmd to power plants. The remaining 6.6 mmscmd was consumed by other sectors like sponge iron plants, LPG, city gas distribution networks and petrochemical/refineries. Minister of State for Petroleum and Natural Gas R P N Singh had last month informed Parliament that output from KG-D6 was short of 70.39 mmscmd envisaged by now as per the field development plan approved in 2006. &quot;The contractor (Reliance) was advised by (oil regulator) DGH to expeditiously drill more development wells in D1 and D3 field as per FDP in order to enhance gas production in KG-DWN-98/3 block,&quot; he had stated. Reliance has so far drilled only 20 out of the committed 22 wells on D1 and D3 as reservoir has not performed on expected lines. Of the 20 wells drilled, only 18 wells are under production. Further in the FDP approved in 2006, Reliance had committed to drill 31 wells by the current fiscal-end. Reliance currently holds 90 per cent interest in KG-D6, while the rest is with Niko Resources of Canada. It is selling 30% in the block and 22 others to UK's BP Plc for USD 7.2 billion. Reliance started natural gas production from KG-D6 fields from April 1, 2009. Its partner Niko had last month stated that &quot;declines (in production) are expected to continue until work-overs are completed and/or additional wells are tied-in&quot;. The present output is less than about 60 mmscmd production in the same period a year-ago.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: CBI may file case against Reliance Industries: Report
description: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) is considering filing a case or multiple cases against Reliance Industries over its operations of its gas block in the Krishna Godavari (KG) basin, the Mint reported on Tuesday.
tags: Business, CBI, Krishna Godavari (KG), Reliance Industries
articleBody: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) is considering filing a case or multiple cases against Reliance Industries over its operations of its gas block in the Krishna Godavari (KG) basin, the Mint reported on Tuesday. The CBI is likely to name officials in the country's upstream regulator and the petroleum ministry in the case, the newspaper said, citing officials at the CBI who declined to be named. Earlier this month, Reliance Industries said there was no evidence to suggest that costs in development of the country's key natural gas field in the KG basin were overstated.  A Reliance Industries spokesman in Mumbai and a spokeswoman for the CBI in New Delhi declined to comment on the newspaper report, when reached by Reuters on Tuesday. &quot;The preliminary inquiry against RIL and others is in final stages and very soon a case will be registered,&quot; one of the officials at the investigative agency told the Mint newspaper, referring to Reliance Industries. The CAG has criticised Reliance Industries and the government over development of a key natural gas field in the KG basin and called for revamping profit sharing arrangements from oil and gas blocks.  The offshore KG basin was expected to contribute up to one-quarter the gas supply for India, but lower-than-expected output has left the energy-hungry nation more dependent on expensive, imported LNG to fuel power and fertiliser plants.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL plans maintenance shut down of units at Jamnagar
description: Reliance Industries today said it is planning maintenance and inspection shutdown of some units at its SEZ refinery in Jamnagar, starting from September 19 to 23.
articleBody: Reliance Industries today said it is planning maintenance and inspection shutdown of some units at its SEZ refinery in Jamnagar, starting from September 19 to 23. The maintenance and inspection shut down would be done for Light Cycle Oil hydrocracker (LCOHC) and Vacuum Gas Oil hydrotreating unit (VGOHT) of SEZ refinery at Jamnagar refinery complex. &quot;These maintenance shutdowns will be for a period of approximately 4 weeks,&quot; RIL said in a filing to the BSE. According to the company, the shutdown of these units is being planned for the first time since commissioning. &quot;Both the refineries at Jamnagar complex are planned to operate at maximum crude processing capacity i.e. 1.3 million barrels per day during this period. &quot;All other major processing units at the complex are also planned to operate at normal capacity,&quot; the filing added. Shares of Reliance Industries closed marginally down at Rs 820.85 on the BSE.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL to shut 2 units at refinery for maintenance
description: Reliance Industries, owner of the world's biggest refining complex, said on Monday it will shut a light cycle oil (LCO) hydrocracker and a vacuum gas oil (VGO) hydrotreater at its 580,000 barrels per day (bpd) export focussed refinery for about four weeks for maintenance.
tags: Business, Refineries, refining complex, Reliance Industries, RIL, shutdown of units
articleBody: Reliance Industries, owner of the world's biggest refining complex, said on Monday it will shut a light cycle oil (LCO) hydrocracker and a vacuum gas oil (VGO) hydrotreater at its 580,000 barrels per day (bpd) export focussed refinery for about four weeks for maintenance. Reliance operates two refineries with a combined capacity to process 1.24 million bpd oil at Jamnagar in Gujarat. This will be the first ever shutdown of units at the refinery, commissioned in December 2008. Reliance said in a statement the LCO unit would be shut from Monday while VGO unit would remain offline from Friday. A VGO hydrotreater removes sulphur and nitrogen content from heavy feedstock to produce feed for units like fluid catalytic crackers, which produce value added products like liquefied petroleum gas and gasoline. The LCO hydrotreater converts LCO -- a low quality diesel fuel blending component -- into naphtha and lighter products.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance defends levy of marketing margin on KG-D6 gas
description: Reliance Industries has strongly defended its decision to impose a marketing margin over-and-above the government-approved sale price for KG-D6 gas, saying the levy was to cover for the risk and cost associated with marketing of gas.
articleBody: Reliance Industries has strongly defended its decision to impose a marketing margin over-and-above the government-approved sale price for KG-D6 gas, saying the levy was to cover for the risk and cost associated with marketing of gas. Responding to upstream oil and gas production regulator DGH reopening the issue, RIL Executive Director P M S Prasad on August 24 wrote to Oil Secretary G C Chaturvedi saying the USD 0.135 per million British thermal units marketing margin is a cost levied beyond the gas delivery flange and as such, is not regulated by the Production Sharing Contract (PSC). The PSC governs fixation of price of gas at the 'delivery point', the point at which an upstream operator transfers custody of gas to a marketing and transportation agency. That point for eastern offshore KG-D6 gas is Kakinada, in Andhra Pradesh, and the government had in 2007 approved a gas price of USD 4.205 per mmBtu at the delivery point. But the DGH wants the USD 0.135 per mmBtu levy added to the gas sale price and profits for RIL and the government to be calculated thereafter. Currently, profits are calculated by deducting capital and the operating cost from the gas sales price only. Prasad, however, said the PSC does not provide for such a move, as the marketing and transportation cost cannot be recovered from revenues earned from sale of oil or gas. Section 3.2 (iii) of the PSC states that &quot;costs of marketing or transportation of petroleum beyond the delivery point are not cost-recoverable. Both marketing and transport costs are clearly recognised as being distinct from the sale price at the delivery point and kept outside the PSC for purposes of cost recovery,&quot; he wrote. He said any attempt to include the margin as part of the price of gas approved under the PSC &quot;will have the effect of making all marketing costs as well as ensuing risks and liabilities cost-recoverable under the PSC.&quot; Moreover, such inclusion can be done only after amendment of the present PSC. The marketing margin is to cover for cost of employees involved in marketing and sales, related infrastructure and all legal and operational expenses that occur beyond the delivery point, as defined in the PSC.  It also covers the credit risk of buyers, litigation costs and penalties such as ship-or-pay reimbursement to transporters and levies for supplying off-spec gas. &quot;Any costs associated with these risks are at the moment not chargeable to the PSC for the purpose of cost-recovery and are not being claimed as such by&quot; RIL, he added. He pointed to state-run ONGC and GAIL charging a marketing margin on government-administered gas, called APM gas, as well as on the produce from the Panna/Mukta and Tapti fields.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL may trade in range of Rs 800-850: SP Tulsian
description: Investment Advisor, SP Tulsian is of the view that Reliance Industries may trade in the range of Rs 800-850 for the next 15 days or so.
articleBody: Investment Advisor, SP Tulsian is of the view that Reliance Industries may trade in the range of Rs 800-850 for the next 15 days or so. Tulsian told CNBC-TV18, &quot;The fall in Reliance Industrie got arrested because we did not see any fresh buying from institutional investors. Selling by institutional investors in the last two months has brought down the share price to Rs 720. I have been maintaining that it does not have potential to move beyond Rs 850. The share is now ruling close to Rs 825. I will still maintain that there is strong resistance for the share to move past Rs 850. I am not talking from an hourly or few days movement perspective, where it can move to Rs 855-860.&quot; He further added, &quot;But I do not think the share can sustain above those levels. On the lower side, the stock has support at Rs 800 in view of tapering of selling by overseas institutional investors. One can expect a range of Rs 800 to Rs 850 for the next 15 days or so.&quot;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL's output from key gas block at 44 mscmd: Regulator
description: Reliance Industries is currently producing 44 mscmd (million standard cubic metres a day) gas from its key D6 block in the Krishna Godavari (KG) basin, the Directorate General Of Hydrocarbons said on Thursday.
tags: Business, Directorate General of Hydrocarbons, Krishna Godavari (KG) Basin, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Reliance Industries is currently producing 44 mscmd (million standard cubic metres a day) gas from its key D6 block in the Krishna Godavari (KG) basin, the Directorate General Of Hydrocarbons said on Thursday. &quot;It's around 44 (mscmd),&quot; Director General of Hydrocarbons S.K. Srivastava told reporters on the sidelines of an industry conference, when asked about the current output from the Reliance block, off the country's east coast. Reliance, controlled by India's richest man Mukesh Ambani, has been under fire in recent months from the regulator, investors and analysts over slowing gas output from its main KG D6 block. The production figure is much lower than the 60 mscmd it produced a year earlier, and far off the planned peak capacity of 80 mscmd. Earlier this year, Reliance sold a 30% stake in 21 oil and gas blocks, some in the KG basin, to BP in a USD 7.2 billion deal, in part to benefit from BP's expertise in deep-water exploration.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: No cost recovery of underutilised facilities for RIL: SGI
description: The Solicitor General of India has held that Reliance Industries should not be allowed to recover the cost of facilities that remain underutilised due to lower than anticipated output at its KG-D6 gas field.
tags: Business, KG-D6, Reliance Industries, Solicitor General of India
articleBody: The Solicitor General of India has held that Reliance Industries should not be allowed to recover the cost of facilities that remain underutilised due to lower than anticipated output at its KG-D6 gas field. &amp;nbsp; RIL has built facilities to handle up to 80 million cubic metres per day of gas but current production is less than 45 mmcmd, a phenomenon that oil regulator DGH blames on drilling of lesser number of wells than what the company had committed in 2006 when it won approval for investing USD 8.8 billion. Sources privy to the development said the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH) had been pressurising RIL to drill the committed 22 wells by March 2011, so that Dhirubhai-1 and 3 fields can produce projected 61.88 mmcmd and MA field (also in the same block) another 8.1 mmcmd. But when RIL, which was not confident of the geology after pressure at current 18 wells fell and some showed water ingress, refused, DGH proposed to allow only proportionate recovery of cost. On DGH insistence, oil ministry sought a view from the second highest law officer of the country. SGI Rohinton F Nariman on August 17 opined that &quot;the cost/expenditure incurred in constructing production/ processing facilities and pipelines that are currently underutilised/have excess capacity cannot be recovered&quot;. The Production Sharing Contract (PSC), however, does not envisage such a move and if oil ministry is to order such a thing, RIL is likely to challenge it and may initiate arbitration proceedings. Sources said no field development plan by any company anywhere in the world, including 40-50 put by state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Corp (ONGC), have gone exactly as per the plans put on paper because of uncertainty involved in behaviour of what lies several thousand feet below the earth. ONGC had on about a dozen occasions changed field development plan for its prime Mumbai High oil and gas fields. RIL is waiting for BP Plc, who has global expertise in deepsea exploration, to come on board before recommencing drilling at KG-D6. Nariman in his opinion states that the government has &quot;an arguable case&quot; to stop RIL from recovering expenditure which had &quot;resulted in excess capacity / under-utilisation of the asset created&quot; on account of its failure to adhere to the 2006 approved field development plan. According to the 2006 plan, RIL was to drill a further 11 wells by March 2012 to raise output to 80 mmscmd and sustain it at those levels for 9 years. RIL has so far spent USD 5.693 billion and has already recovered USD 5.258 billion from sale of gas. Nariman advised that to the extent RIL has already recovered capital expenditure from sale of gas, &quot;the cost entitlement of the contractor can be reversed&quot;. The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) in its report on KG-D6 field audit, which was tabled in Parliament earlier this month, had not commented on reasonability of RIL hiking the capital expenditure at the nation's biggest gas field from USD 2.4 billion proposed in 2004 to USD 8.8 billion estimate in 2006. It, however, stated that with the gas output from KG-D6 falling to about 43 million standard cubic meters per day, which is close to 40 mmscmd output level envisaged in the 2004 investment plan, raised &quot;doubts if upgradation to 80 mmscmd with substantial increase in development cost (to USD 8.8 billion) was justified&quot;. RIL submitted an initial development plan (IDP) for Dhirubhai-1 and 3 gas finds in May 2004 with capital expenditure of USD 2.4 billion. This was followed up with an Addendum to the IDP (AIDP) in October 2006 proposing USD 5.2 billion capex in Phase-1 and USD 3.6 billion in Phase-II. &quot;Most procurement activities were undertaken late in the line with the schedules of the IDP of May 2004. By contrast, activities in respect of items in the AIDP were initiated even before the submission/approval of the AIDP. Clearly, the development activities of the operator were guided by AIDP, rather than IDP,&quot; CAG had said in the report.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Fresh controversy over RIL's KGD6 marketing margin: Sources
description: Looks like oil &amp; gas major Reliance's KG-D6 problems will never end. There is a fresh controversy over RIL levying a marketing margin for supplying gas from the KGD6, reports CNBC-TV18 quoting sources.
tags: British thermal, Business, Oil & Gas, Reliance, RIL, Sutanu Behuria
articleBody: Looks like oil &amp;amp; gas major Reliance's KG-D6 problems will never end. There is a fresh controversy over RIL levying a marketing margin for supplying gas from the KGD6, reports CNBC-TV18 quoting sources.  The fertilizer secretary Sutanu Behuria last week wrote to his counterpart in the oil ministry questioning the admissibility of this levy as well as its quantum of 13 cents per million British thermal units.&amp;nbsp; The fertiliser secretary said the companies have been paying this levy since May 2009, which has led to huge under recoveries.  Behuria also pointed out that the companies getting gas from the KG-D6 have still not been reimbursed for this marketing margin levy and that it would not be possible to do so until the oil ministry or the gas EGOM provide some clarity on the issue which has now been pending for over a year. Also read: Cairn shareholders okay conditions for Vedanta stake buy

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Rakesh Patil'}
headline: Abhijit Paul's view on Reliance, L&amp;T
description: Abhijit Paul, AVP-Technical Analyst, Brics Securities feels that Reliance and L&amp;T actually managed to give a bounce back, which was pretty good in terms of price as well as in terms of volumes.
tags: Abhijit Paul, AVP - Technical Analyst, Brics Securities, L&T, Reliance, Stocks Views
articleBody: Abhijit Paul, AVP-Technical Analyst, Brics Securities feels that Reliance and L&amp;amp;T actually managed to give a bounce back, which was pretty good in terms of price as well as in terms of volumes. Paul told CNBC-TV18, &quot;Reliance and L&amp;amp;T actually managed to give a bounce back, which was pretty good in terms of price as well as in terms of volumes. My sense is both the stocks, both are Nifty 50 heavyweight stocks are likely to stay within the range. We may see Nifty trying to test its previous low 4718. Banks may fall below that. Metals are very likely to fall below that. But Reliance and L&amp;amp;T are those odd stocks which are I sense will continue to stay within this range and this range is supported by the current lows. So from here on I sense with a one week or two weeks timeframe, these two stocks will stay within a range.&quot;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Rakesh Patil'}
headline: RIL has support around Rs 780-760: LKP
description: Reliance Industries has support at around Rs 780-760, says Rakesh Gandhi, Senior Tech Analyst at LKP.
tags: Rakesh Gandhi, Reliance Industries, Senior Tech Analyst at LKP, Stocks Views
articleBody: Reliance Industries has support at around Rs 780-760, says Rakesh Gandhi, Senior Tech Analyst at LKP. Gandhi told CNBC-TV18, &quot;Reliance's chart is a bit different. I think 10% bounce that we have seen in last three weeks and bounced back 20% from the lows that we saw; Rs 719 or Rs 715 that was the low that we saw when market was around 4,750. So it has bounced back 20% and it is not retraced much in the last two days compared to what other stocks have done, so the support for Reliance at this point of time is Rs 780 and Rs 760 between this it has a huge support and if it does not break it could stay above that though market makes a new low.&quot; Disclosure: I do not have any exposure but at LKP we are regularly recommending the stock.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Reliance says KG D6 costs were not overstated
description: Energy major Reliance Industries said on Friday there was no evidence to suggest that costs in development of the country's key natural gas field in the Krishna Godavari (KG) basin were overstated.
tags: , Business, Comptroller and Auditor General, Ernst & Young, KG-D6, Krishna-Godavari basin, LNG, natural gas field, production sharing contract, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Energy major Reliance Industries said on Friday there was no evidence to suggest that costs in development of the country's key natural gas field in the Krishna Godavari (KG) basin were overstated. The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) has criticised Reliance and the government over development of KG-D6 basin and called for revamping profit sharing arrangements from oil and gas blocks.  The offshore KG basin was expected to contribute up to one-quarter the gas supply for India, but lower-than-expected output has left the energy-hungry nation more dependent on expensive, imported LNG to fuel power and fertiliser plants. Global consulting firm Ernst &amp;amp; Young found no evidence suggesting KG D6 costs were overstated in purchases from third parties or from related parties, Reliance said on Friday, a day after the auditor submitted the report to parliament. The KG D6 project was completed in a timely manner despite hostile weather conditions and significant supply chain constraints, Reliance said. &quot;The KG D6 project faced considerable physical and execution environment challenges as well as difficulties faced in the E&amp;amp;P capital projects market,&quot; it said, citing findings of IPA Inc, an independent project evaluation consultant. The auditor's report had said Reliance, the operator of the KG-DWN-98/3 block, was allowed to violate terms of its production sharing contract. The auditor does not have prosecuting power, but its findings can form the basis of any possible government action against Reliance, as well as future policy on exploration.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: CAG for autonomy to DGH; Arm's length relation with OilMin
description: Government auditor CAG today said that the Directorate General of Hydrocarbon (DGH) should be given autonomy in discharging regulatory functions while working at arm's length with the oil ministry.
articleBody: Government auditor CAG today said that the Directorate General of Hydrocarbon (DGH) should be given autonomy in discharging regulatory functions while working at arm's length with the oil ministry. In its much-awaited audit report of fields operated by firms like Reliance Industries, the Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG) said that the role of the DGH be clearly demarcated into regulatory and technical functions. DGH, which advises Oil Ministry on technical issues concerning oil and gas exploration and production, is not an independent entity, Deputy CAG Rekha Gupta said at a press conference called to brief about the findings in the report that was tabled in Parliament today. The CAG wanted DGH separated from the executive. &quot;They are regulator and they should not have executive powers. There should be an arm's length distance between executive and regulator,&quot; Gupta added. &quot;In our view the roles and functions of DGH encompass two sets of functions with potential conflict of interest -- an upstream regulatory function, and a function of rendering technical advice of government of India. Consequently, werecommend that the functions currently discharged by the DGH be clearly demarcated,&quot; it said. CAG said while the technical advisory and related functions should be discharged by a body wholly under the Petroleum Ministry, regulatory functions; like review of hydrocarbon reserves and reservoir management; should be discharged by an autonomous body that will work in close coordination of the government.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: CAG rebukes RIL on scope of audit of KG-D6 fields
description: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) has rebuked Reliance Industries on scope of audit of its eastern offshore KG-D6 fields, saying the audit was to verify if government revenues were protected.
tags: Business, CAG, Comptroller and Auditor General, KG-D6 fields, Reliance Industries
articleBody: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) has rebuked Reliance Industries on scope of audit of its eastern offshore KG-D6 fields, saying the audit was to verify if government revenues were protected. Reliance had challenged the scope, extent and coverage of CAG audit at various points, including as late as the Exit Conference the top auditor held in July to conclude the audit. &quot;We do not agree with the operator's (Reliance's) views regarding our audit scope, extent and coverage,&quot; CAG said in its final report tabled in Parliament today. Reliance had stated that CAG's scope was limited to verification of charges and credits (authenticity of expenditure) and inspection of books and records and did not permit an audit of the operational, commercial and technical decisions. &quot;One of our key audit objectives was to verify whether the revenue interests of the government (including royalty and Government of India share of profit petroleum) were properly protected,&quot; CAG said. Verification of charges and credits relating to the contractor's activities were not merely limited to an arithmetical totalling. &quot;Such an exercise would extend to verifying whether the costs being depicted in the Production Sharing Contract (PSC) accounts by the contractor, which would critically affect the determination of profit petroleum and government's share therein, are correctly determined,&quot; it said. The CAG emphasised that all its enquiries and findings emerge from and were limited to the PSC. &quot;We do not profess to go into a procedure or policy related aspects leading to the conclusion of the PSC.&quot; &quot;The challenge of the operator (Reliance) with regard to the experience of the institution of the CAG in conducting audit of oil and gas exploration and production (E&amp;amp;P) is unwarranted. &quot;This institution has been conducting audit of India's largest E&amp;amp;P company, ONGC as well as Oil India Ltd for several decades. The collective audit expertise of our institution is adequate to meet the challenges of scrutiny of hydrocarbon PSC,&quot; it added. In its response, the oil ministry in July, 2011, had agreed that scope of audit conducted by the CAG was within the common audit parameters and indicated that financial or accounting audit also envisages review of activities and resources contributing to financial events and the controls thereon.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: CAG wants Cairn field cost increase to be audited as well
description: While Reliance Industries raising KG-D6 field capex from USD 2.4 billion to USD 8.8 billion have been subject matter of various scrutinies, top auditor CAG wants a similar increase in spending by Cairn India on its Rajasthan oilfields to be audited in future.
tags: Business, CAG, Cairn India, field development plan, KG-D6 field, oilfields, Parliament, Reliance Industries
articleBody: While Reliance Industries raising KG-D6 field capex from USD 2.4 billion to USD 8.8 billion have been subject matter of various scrutinies, top auditor CAG wants a similar increase in spending by Cairn India on its Rajasthan oilfields to be audited in future. The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) in its final report on Rajasthan block audit, tabled in Parliament, said Cairn had in 2006 proposed USD 1.24 billion for developing the Mangala oil field in the block. A revised field development plan (FDP) was submitted three years later in 2009 due to change in delivery point of crude oil from Barmer in Rajasthan to Salaya and later to Bhogat in Gujarat, which necessitated laying of pipeline. &quot;On June 30, 2009, the Management Committee approved the revised FDP at a cost of USD 2.367 billion, plus USD 941.05 million as the cost of the pipeline, plus USD 35.61 million as cost of Mangala (field) enhanced oil recovery (scheme); ie a total cost of USD 3.34 billion,&quot; it said. The increase in revised FDP was primarily attributed to nearly doubling of upstream capital cost during 2005 and 2007, increase in rig hiring charges and delay in project schedule. Reliance too had cited more or less similar reasons for raising capex for Dhirubhai-1 and 3 gas finds in the prolific KG-D6 block from USD 2.4 billion proposed in May 2004 to USD 8.8 billion (USD 5.2 billion in Phase-1 and rest in Phase-II) in October 2006 as it built facilities to handle 80 million standard cubic meters per day as against 40 mmscmd previously. The CAG said the oil ministry had informed that the increase in capex was also due to changes in the production facilities in view of increased production rates from 100,000 barrels per day to 125,000 barrels per day. &quot;Most of the expenditure under the revised FDP (of Cairn) has been/would be incurred from 2008-09 and thereafter; this would be covered in future audits,&quot; it said. The auditor said USD 201.54 million expense incurred by Cairn on works like exploration in development area DA-1, should not be eligible for cost recovery. &quot;We also found excess expenditure of USD 27.63 million on pre-development and development activities over the approved budget for 2007-08 of USD 160.56 million, which has not been ratified by the MC,&quot; it said. The CAG said 13 fresh discoveries were made during or between the appraisal phase and in the development phase in areas already delineated as development areas. &quot;Consequently, in our opinion, the declaration of fresh discoveries during the appraisal/ development phases within delineated discovery/development areas amounted to irregular extension of exploration activities, which is not consonance with the terms of the PSC,&quot; it said. &quot;This also indicates that the discovery/development areas were not strictly delineated, and included excess area,&quot; CAG said. &quot;Further, there were instances of non-compliance with regard to the PSC provisions for notification of potential commercial interest, appraisal programme, submission of field development plans etc,&quot; it added.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: CAG critical of RIL, Oil Ministry on KG-D6 contract
description: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) today sharply criticised Reliance Industries and the Oil Ministry for violation of contract over the showpiece KG-D6 gas block and called for revamping the current profit-sharing arrangement that reduces government revenues.
tags: Business, Comptroller and Auditor General, KG-D6 gas block, oil ministry, Reliance Industries
articleBody: The Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) today sharply criticised Reliance Industries and the Oil Ministry for violation of contract over the showpiece KG-D6 gas block and called for revamping the current profit-sharing arrangement that reduces government revenues. The much-awaited final audit report of CAG, which was tabled in Parliament today, however did not quantify how much the government lost when Reliance hiked the capital expenditure at the nation's biggest gas field from USD 2.4 billion proposed in 2004 to USD 8.8 billion estimate in 2006. The CAG faulted the Oil Ministry and its technical arm, the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH), for allowing Reliance to retain the entire 7,645 sq km KG-DWN-98/3 (KG-D6) block in the Bay of Bengal after the giant Dhirubhai-1 and 3 gas finds were made in 2001. &quot;We could not derive assurance regarding reasonableness of costs incurred, primarily due to lack of adequate competition (in bidding for contract)... with consequential adverse implications for cost recovery and Government ofIndia's financial take,&quot; the report said. The CAG said with the gas output from KG-D6 falling to about 43 million standard cubic meters per day which is close to 40 mmscmd output level envisaged in the 2004 investment plan, raised &quot;doubts if upgradation to 80 mmscmd with substantial increase in development cost (to USD 8.8 billion)was justified.&quot; Maintaining it was yet to see the report for detailed comments, Reliance in a press statement said, &quot;We reiterate that, as a contractor, we remain committed to complying with the PSC provisions and procedures including adopting Good International Petroleum Industry Practices (GIPIP) in ouroperations,&quot; it said. The official auditor was unhappy about the lack of adequate oversight and government control over procurements done by private firms and wanted high value purchases to be more specifically approved by government representatives. It wanted &quot;in-depth review&quot; of 10 contracts, including the eight awarded to Aker Group by Reliance on a single-bid basis. In particular it was critical of the USD 1.1 billion contract to put up a production facility at MA oilfield in the same KG-D6 block to Aker on a single bid basis after disqualifying other qualified bidders. The CAG faulted the Oil Ministry and its technical arm, the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH), for allowing Reliance to retain the entire 7,645 sq km KG-DWN-98/3 (KG-D6) block in the Bay of Bengal after the giant Dhirubhai-1 and 3 gas finds were made in 2001. As per the PSC, Reliance should have relinquished 25% of the total area outside the discoveries in June, 2004, and 2005, but the entire block was declared as a discovery area and the company was allowed to retain it. &quot;We recommend that the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas should review the determination of the entire contract area as 'discovery area' strictly in terms of the PSC provisions,&quot; the CAG said, asking for delineation of the discovery area and relinquishment of the rest. CAG sought review of the production sharing contracts, like the one Reliance had signed for KG-D6 in 1999 when BJP-led NDA was in power, saying the regime was designed to encourage hike capital expenditure by private contractors thereby reducing the government's share. &quot;Given the similar conclusions that two independent agencies have reached as regards the adverse impact of the profit sharing mechanism in protecting Government of India's share designed in the late 1990s, there does seem to be enough ground to revisit the formula,&quot; it said. CAG said the current PSC regime provides &quot;substantial incentive to increase capital expenditure or 'front-end' capital expenditure&quot; so that government take from the blocks is lower. For future PSCs, CAG recommended that the Investment-Multiple linkage with the profit sharing formula be removed. &quot;Instead, the biddable profit-sharing percentage should be a single percentage. This will reduce the incentive for skewed volume and timing of capital expenditure resulting in very low Government of India share of profit petroleum. &quot;Further, in order to ensure a modicum of control, very high value procurement decisions above a specified limit should be subject to approval by the Management Committee, more specifically the approval of the Government of India representatives,&quot; it said. On Reliance's KG-D6 cost capex increase, it said &quot;approval of estimates (first USD 2.4 billion and then USD 8.8 billion in 2006) does not constitute acceptance of the cost projects&quot;, which can be done only through an audit of the actual cost incurred. Reliance submitted an initial development plan (IDP) for Dhirubhai-1 and 3 gas finds in May 2004 with capital expenditure of USD 2.4 billion. This was followed up with an Addendum to the IDP (AIDP) in October 2006 proposing USD 5.2 billion capex in Phase-1 and USD 3.6 billion in Phase-II. &quot;Most procurement activities were undertaken late in the line with the schedules of the IDP of May 2004. By contrast, activities in respect of items in the AIDP were initiated even before the submission/approval of the AIDP. Clearly, the development activities of the operator were guided by AIDP, rather than IDP,&quot; it said. While expenditure incurred in 2006-07 and 2007-08 was audited by CAG, remaining expenditure incurred from 2008-09 onwards would be covered in the future audit. CAG faulted Reliance for awarding a USD 1.1 billion contract to put up a production facility at MA oilfield in the same KG-D6 block to Aker on a single bid basis. &quot;During our scrutiny of the operator's records, we have come across instances, where multiple vendors were pre-qualified. However, when technical bids were received, all vendors (except one) were rejected, and the contract was finally awarded on a single financial bid,&quot; it said. CAG said such disqualification of vendors on technical grounds, after a pre-qualification process and bidders' meeting for technical clarifications, limits the competitiveness which was not in accordance to the PSC. Seeking in-depth review in the award of 10 contracts (of which 8 were awarded to Aker Group companies), it said, &quot;We are not even remotely suggesting that the operator should follow government procurement procedures, yet any commercially prudent private acquisition would also attempt to generate competition and thereby obtain the most competitive price.&quot;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'Rakesh Patil'}
headline: Invest in RIL on dips: Dilip Bhat
description: Invest in Reliance Industries (RIL) at lower levels with a long term perspective, says Dilip Bhat, Joint MD, Prabhudas Lilladher.
tags: Dilip Bhat, Joint MD, Prabhudas Lilladher, Reliance Industries, RIL, Stocks Views
articleBody: Invest in Reliance Industries (RIL) at lower levels with a long term perspective, says Dilip Bhat, Joint MD, Prabhudas Lilladher. Bhat told CNBC-TV18, &quot;I am sure that the CAG report was probably weighing on the mind of lot of investors and given the environment we are at the moment it probably could get a little worse on that particular front. But having said that RIL itself has corrected so seriously, first and foremost largely on account of the KG Gas production has really come down quite a bit and that is where a lot of analysts were expecting that the production ramp up should also bring in a commensurate cash flow notwithstanding the fact that this has been approved and justified by a deal with BP.&quot; He further added, &quot;As far as RIL is concerned there could be some downside from the current levels but that would be a time to really invest on a slightly longer term basis.&quot;

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL complies with PSC, good industry practice in KG-D6
description: With the CAG criticising it for violating the contract for its showpiece KG-D6 gas fields, Reliance Industries today said it remains compliant with all contractual provisions, including following good international industry practice.
tags: Business, CAG, Comptroller and Auditor General, good international industry practice, Good International Petroleum Industry Practices, KG-D6 gas fields, Parliament, production sharing contract, Reliance Industries
articleBody: With the CAG criticising it for violating the contract for its showpiece KG-D6 gas fields, Reliance Industries today said it remains compliant with all contractual provisions, including following good international industry practice. Reliance, in a press statement, said it cannot comment on the final audit findings of the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) on the KG-D6 block for 2006-07 and 2007-08, which were tabled in Parliament today, as it was yet to see the report. &quot;We reiterate that, as a contractor, we remain committed to complying with the Production Sharing Contract (PSC) provisions and procedures, including adopting Good International Petroleum Industry Practices (GIPIP) in our operations,&quot; it said. Reliance said it had provided the Oil Ministry, the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH) and CAG with detailed comments on the draft audit report that was communicated to it. &quot;Since many of the comments in the draft report had referred to issues that were technical in nature, we had offered to the CAG a complete and thorough interaction with subject matter specialists,&quot; it said. &quot;We remain open to such interaction at all times,&quot; it added. &quot;We maintain that, in KG-D6, Reliance has set a global benchmark for effective, efficient project completion and capital cost-competitiveness under the most trying circumstances and we are proud of our achievements,&quot; the statement said. Even the CAG had appreciated Reliance effort. &quot;We appreciate the efforts of the operator in executing this world-class mega-greenfield deepwater oil and gas infrastructure in India within record time,&quot; the CAG report said. The Mukesh Ambani-run firm said it has and will continue to cooperate with the government on audits, as per the provisions of the PSC.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: CAG lambasts Reliance: Investors say 'So what?'
description: Reliance Industries (RIL) stock gained rose 2% even after the release of the CAG report accusing the oil and gas major for having violating the production sharing contract (PSC) in its D6 block in KG Basin.
tags: Business, CAG, DGH, KG basin, RIL, SP Tulsian
articleBody: Moneycontrol Bureau Shares of Reliance Industries (RIL)&amp;nbsp;gained&amp;nbsp;2%, on Thursday, even after the release of the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) lambasted the oil and gas major for violating the production sharing contract (PSC) in its D6 block in KG Basin.  The report&amp;nbsp;critisised&amp;nbsp;RIL for hoarding D6 exploration acreage despite lack of rigs. It questioned why RIL was allowed to enter the second and third exploration phases of the blocks without giving up 25% of the contract area in each, by treating the entire area as a discovery area. But the stern criticism seemed to have&amp;nbsp;no effect&amp;nbsp;on the&amp;nbsp;stock&amp;nbsp;as it&amp;nbsp;did not&amp;nbsp;lose much footing --&amp;nbsp;falling&amp;nbsp;just&amp;nbsp;a percent&amp;nbsp;immediately after the report was tabled. According to investment advisor SP Tulsian, the report has not shaken business fundamentals of the company. &quot;Infact, the report suggests that the Director General of Hydrocarbons (DGH) should have stopped RIL from proceeding gas production from its oil wells in KG-D6 basin.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: RIL violated production sharing pact on KG-D6: CAG
description: The CAG report says Reliance industries violated the production sharing pact but the DGH and Petroleum Ministry are equally to blame being ill-equipped to oversee the production sharing contract.
tags: Business, CAG, KG-D6 gas fields, Reliance Industries
articleBody: Moneycontrol Bureau The Comptroller and Auditor General's (CAG) final audit report on Reliance Industries' (RIL) offshore KG-D6 gas fields expenditure was tabled in the Parliament. Experts say the report, tabled in Parliament today, is a watered down version.  The report says Reliance industries violated the production sharing pact but the DGH and Petroleum Ministry are equally to blame being ill-equipped to oversee the production sharing contract. It&amp;nbsp;questioned why&amp;nbsp;Reliance was allowed to enter the second and third exploration phases of the blocks without giving up 25% of the contract area in each, by treating the entire area as a discovery area. As per the PSC, Reliance should have relinquished 25% of the total area outside the discoveries in June, 2004, and 2005, but the entire block was declared as a discovery area and the company was allowed to retain it. It faulted the Oil Ministry and its technical arm, the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH), for allowing Reliance to retain the entire 7,645 sq km KG-DWN-98/3 (KG-D6) block in the Bay of Bengal after the giant Dhirubhai-1 and 3 gas finds were made in 2001. &quot;We recommend that the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas should review the determination of the entire contract area as 'discovery area' strictly in terms of the PSC provisions,&quot; the CAG said, asking for delineation of the discovery area and relinquishment of the rest. Meanwhile, Reliance has issued a release saying, &quot;We are unable to comment on the contents as we have not yet seen the Final Audit Report.&quot;  Coming on down hard on the government, the CAG faulted its oversight, particularly on high value procurement decisions, and sought an &quot;in-depth review&quot; of 10 contracts, including eight awarded to Aker Group by Reliance on a single-bid basis. However, giving Reliance a little reprieve on charges of 'gold-plating' its KG-D6 expenses, the CAG said &quot;approval of estimates (first USD 2.4 billion and then USD 8.8 billion in 2006) does not constitute acceptance of the cost projects&quot;, which can be done only through an audit of the actual cost incurred. (With inputs from PTI) sagar.salvi@network18online.com

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: UK-based BG Group in talks to buy stake in ONGC's assets
description: The UK's energy company BG Group is in talks to acquire a stake in the state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Corp's gas discovery block off the east coast, the company's India head Walter Simpson said today.
tags: BG Group, Business, gas discovery block, KG-D6 fields, Krishna-Godavari basin, Oil and Natural Gas Corp
articleBody: The UK's energy company BG Group is in talks to acquire a stake in the state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Corp's gas discovery block off the east coast, the company's India head Walter Simpson said today.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  &quot;We spoke to ONGC number of months ago... rather almost an year ago for picking up (a) stake in their oil assets... the proposal is with them,&quot; BG India President and Managing Director Walter Simpson told reporters on the sidelines of the World Energy Policy Summit here.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  The Krishna Godavari basin deepsea block KG-DWN-98/2 sits next to Reliance Industries' prolific KG-D6 fields in Bay of Bengal.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  ONGC has discovered 3.42 trillion cubic feet of inplace gas reserves in the block, of which 1.904 Tcf is recoverable.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  Officials in the state firm said ONGC was in discussions with 3-4 foreign firms, including London stock Exchange-listed energy major BG Group with expertise to exploit deep-sea discoveries.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  &quot;We have plans to start production from this block in 2016-17,&quot; said an ONGC official.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  Cairn India has 10% stake in the block while ONGC owns the remaining 90%.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  ONGC has submitted Declaration of Commerciality for the Northern and Southern Discovery Area in the block. The northern part of the block has seven finds which it plans to tie-up with two other gas discoveries in an adjacent block.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  Once sector regulator DGH approves the commercial viability of the finds, ONGC will make a formal field development plan (FDP) outlining the specifics of producing gas from the find.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  ONGC has tentatively pegged the investment required for bringing to production the Padmawati, Kanakadurga, Annapurna, N-1, D/KT, U, A, W and E gas finds in the Northern Discovery Area (NDA) of the block at over USD 7.7 billion.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  In the southern part is the ultra deep sea UD-1 find that will be developed separately.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  Simpson said BG India plans to drill more well on the Panna/Mukta and Tapti oil and gas fields off the west coast. BG has 30% interest in the fields where ONGC has 40% and Reliance Industries the remaining 30%.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  &quot;We are looking at drilling more wells in the PMT fields,&quot; he said.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  BG Group plans to invest USD 500 million in India's oil exploration and production sector in the next five years.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: Oil Min chides DGH for reopening RIL marketing margin issue
description: The Oil Ministry has rebuked its technical arm, the DGH, for reopening the issue of the marketing margin that RIL charges on selling KG-D6 gas, but may seek the Law Ministry's opinion to ascertain if the firm can be asked to share those revenues with the government.
tags: Business, DGH, KG-D6, oil ministry, RIL
articleBody: The Oil Ministry has rebuked its technical arm, the DGH, for reopening the issue of the marketing margin that RIL charges on selling KG-D6 gas, but may seek the Law Ministry's opinion to ascertain if the firm can be asked to share those revenues with the government.  The ministry has conveyed its displeasure to the Directorate General of Hydrocarbons (DGH) at the highest levels over the reopening of a long-settled issue, sources privy to the development said. It feels the DGH is wrongly interpreting the contract, which clearly states that the government is entitled to get a share of the price of gas at the delivery point. On the other hand, the marketing margin charged by the Mukesh Ambani-led firm is to intended to cover the risk involved in carrying gas from that delivery point to customers' door-step. The DGH recently asked Reliance to add the USD 0.135 per million British thermal units marketing margin to the KG-D6 gas price of USD 4.205 per mmBtu for the purpose of calculation of the government's profit take. Sources said the ministry feels a Pandora's Box will be opened if the DGH move is approved, as public sector firms like GAIL India, too, have been charging a marketing margin, which is higher than what is being levied by Reliance, for several years now. The same principle will have to be applied to gas produced from state-owned Oil and Natural Gas Corp (ONGC), which is marketed by GAIL. But to settle the issue once and for all, the ministry plans seek an opinion from the Law Ministry, they said. The DGH demand also runs contrary to the stance the Oil Ministry took on the issue in Parliament last year. The then-Oil Minister Murli Deora had on February 24, 2010, told the Rajya Sabha that the marketing margin was a bilateral issue between the seller (Reliance) and the buyers.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;  The government approved the price for gas sales at the delivery point of the KG-D6 field as per the provisions of the Production Sharing Contract inked with Reliance. &quot;The said price (USD 4.2 mmBtu) does not include any charge beyond the PSC delivery point. The marketing margin (levied by Reliance) is beyond the delivery point and arises as a result of the gas sale and purchase agreement signed between the seller and the buyer,&quot; Deora had stated. The PSC provides for sharing of revenues from the sale of gas between the government and the contractor at the said price at the delivery point. It does not envisage sharing of revenues earned by the contractor from marketing margins with the government, he had further said. The marketing margin was in lieu of the risks and costs incurred by the contractor on marketing the gas. It is to cover risks like seller liabilities in case of non-supply, customers drawing less than their quota, non-payment of dues and settlement of disputes.  Sources said the DGH wanted the marketing margin to be added to the gas sale price of USD 4.20 per mmBtu so that profit-sharing between the contractor and the government is calculated at the total price of USD 4.335 per mmBtu charged by RIL from its customers. At present, Reliance and the government split profits at the gas sales price of USD 4.20 per mmBtu after deducting the project cost. Besides marketing risks, the USD 0.135 per mmBtu margin is charged by Reliance on account of its extensive efforts to identify customers, execute and manage gas sales and purchase agreements (GSPAs), as well as gas sales planning, daily gas sales operations, gas accounting and invoicing and collection, sources said. The Anil Dhirubhai Ambani Group had in 2009 opposed the levy of a marketing margin by RIL, but agreed to pay it unconditionally after an Oil Ministry clarification. Other gas marketers like state-run GAIL India also charge a marketing margin. GAIL charges a USD 0.18 per mmBtu margin on the sale of regasified-LNG and about USD 0.12 per mmBtu for gas from fields like Panna/Mukta and Tapti and Ravva.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: BP may take 2 years to raise output at RIL's D6 block
description: BP Plc is confident of raising output from the key gas field of Reliance Industries Ltd in about two years, a senior executive at the British company said on Tuesday.
tags: BP plc, Business, D6, KG basin, Reliance Industries
articleBody: BP Plc is confident of raising output from the key gas field of Reliance Industries Ltd in about two years, a senior executive at the British company said on Tuesday. In July, India's cabinet had approved Reliance's plan to sell 30% stake in 21 oil and gas blocks to BP as part of a USD 7.2 billion deal, making it one of the largest investments in India's oil and gas sector.  &quot;We have just received the approval. We are studying the data. We are confident that there is more gas and output can be raised. But these things take time, it may take a couple of years,&quot; BP India head Sashi Mukundan said. Reliance Industries, the country's largest listed firm, has been under pressure over the past few months from an industry regulator and investors over slowing gas output from its main D6 block in the KG basin off the Andhra Pradesh coast. In May, the director general of hydrocarbons said the company was producing 48 mscmd (million standard cubic metres per day of gas) from the block, lower than 60 mscmd it produced last year and far off the planned peak capacity of 80 mscmd. But India's approval of Reliance's plan to sell stake in some oil and gas blocks to BP is expected to aid the Indian company in boosting output from the deepwater blocks. Shares in Reliance rose as much as 3.6% on Tuesday in the Mumbai market that was up 0.6%. The stock is down more than 20% so far this year, mainly triggered by concerns about slowing D6 output.

author: {'@type': 'Person', 'name': 'webtech_news18'}
headline: HC terms plea against RIL on KG Basin as 'pre-mature'
description: The Delhi High Court today termed as &quot;pre-mature&quot; a plea against Mukesh Ambani-led RIL seeking cancellation of its license granted for exploration of gas in the Krishna-Godavari Basin.
tags: Business, Delhi High Court, exploration of gas, Krishna-Godavari basin, Mukesh Ambani-led RIL, Reliance Industries
articleBody: The Delhi High Court today termed as &quot;pre-mature&quot; a plea against Mukesh Ambani-led Reliance Industries (RIL) seeking cancellation of its license granted for exploration of gas in the Krishna-Godavari Basin. A bench headed by Chief Justice Dipak Misra allowed Mohd Furqan, a journalist, to withdraw his petition and file it at an &quot;appropriate time&quot; on the ground that it was &quot;premature and inadequate.&quot; The bench, however, said he can file a fresh petition at a later stage. &quot;We allow to withdraw the writ petition and file it at an appropriate time. The prayer is allowed,&quot; the bench, also comprising Justice Pradeep Nandrajog, said. The petition had sought a direction to the government for cancellation of license of RIL for exploration of gas in the KG basin alleging the firm, as per the CAG report, had increased the expenditure for exploration almost four times. &quot;How we can direct the Centre to cancel the license&quot;? the court said, adding there was absence of detailed data about the KG basin. The journalist cited the CAG report saying the increase in the expenditure of the company was deductible before sharing the revenue with the Government. The report of the auditing body was&amp;nbsp;a&amp;nbsp;&quot;preliminary&quot; one which is not &quot;justiciable&quot; and hence, the plea was &quot;pre-mature and inadequate, the court said. The High Court had on August 24 decided to constitute a special bench to hear a plea seeking a direction to the government for cancellation of license granted to RIL for exploration of gas in the Krishna-Godavari basin. The decision to refer the matter before a special bench was taken by the Chief Justice as Justice Sanjiv Khanna, who was sitting with him in the bench, had recused from hearing the case. Justice Khanna did not spell out the reasons for opting out of the hearing of the case. The petitioner had also sought a direction to the Centre to take over the control and management of the KG gas project immediately from the JV. He said even after CAG reported &quot;serious violation&quot; of rules in the KG basin, the government is not taking any action though he has made several representations to the Centre in this regard. The central government has granted license to a joint venture of RIL and NICO for exploitation of natural resources of the KG basin. In the petition it was alleged that the JV has cheated the government by inflating the expenditure as there is a provision in the revenue-sharing agreement that RIL is entitled to recover all expenses before sharing it with the government. &quot;Under the revenue-sharing agreement between the government and the JV, the JV is allowed to recover all costs before revenue is shared. The higher the cost of the JV, the revenue available to the government will be lower. Byinflating the expenditure... the JV has cheated the government and their license is liable to be cancelled,&quot; it said. Earlier, the petitioner had moved Supreme Court which had directed him to approach the high court.
